The retailers, along with Michaels and others, acted after pressure from regulators, lawmakers, and parent advocates
Amid mounting pressure, Amazon, Walmart, and Target tell Consumer Reports that they have changed their policies on water beads: The companies will no longer allow the products to be sold if they are being marketed for children. 
“In the interest of safety, Amazon will no longer allow the sale of water beads that are marketed to children, including as toys, art supplies, or for sensory play,” an Amazon spokesperson told CR. “We work hard to ensure the products offered in our store are safe, and we have teams dedicated to developing and updating our policies, evaluating listings, and continuously monitoring our store to prevent unsafe and noncompliant products from being listed.”
Amazon’s sellers will have to comply with the new policy by Dec. 22. The company says that the popular water bead brand Orbeez will now be prohibited and that water beads sold as ammunition for “gel blaster” guns will not be allowed if they are marketed for children.
Walmart tells CR it will prohibit the sale of all water bead toys and craft supplies that are marketed for children under age 9, both in stores and online.
Target initially declined to comment, but after the publication of this story, the company told CR that it has also decided to change its policy regarding water beads.
“At Target, our top priority is the safety of our guests,” said Emily Bisek, a Target spokesperson. “Given growing safety...[Content truncated]

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses the banning of water bead toys marketed towards children due to safety concerns, but it does not relate to Walmart-brand water turning into a dangerous gelatin substance. The connection to the claim is tenuous at best.

Shooting of teen in Goddard Walmart parking lot spotlights concerns with ‘Orbeez Challenge’
===========================================================================================
By  and 
Published: Jun. 5, 2024 at 10:33 PM CDT
WICHITA, Kan. (KWCH) - New information released Wednesday provides information into what police said led up to . A document that 12 News obtained details circumstances surrounding the shooting of an 18-year-old and the arrest of 47-year-old Ruben Contreras.
Contreras is charged with attempted first-degree murder in connection with the May 11 shooting of the teen.
Court documents say the teen and two of his friends were driving around the Walmart parking, allegedly shooting a gel blaster at people. Contreras’ daughter was one of the people the teens allegedly shot at. She called her father.
Detectives said Contreras arrived in the parking lot and attempted to confront the teens as they were in a car backing out of a parking space. That’s when Contreras ran to the driver’s side and appeared to pull out a gun, firing one round into the vehicle, and striking the driver. The car continued forward and crashed.
The driver remained in the car while his friends ran away, police said. Contreras remained at the scene and was taken into custody.
The shooting highlights a social media game called the “Orbeez Challenge.” in which teens use a gel blaster that shoots water-based gel beads. Across the U.S., police report seeing cases where kids take the challenge too far, even freezing the beads. The action leads to criminal charges.
This week, 12 News is taking a closer look into the issues surrounding the “Orbeez Challenge.” We spoke with a teen named Tomas...[Content truncated]

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence alludes to a social media trend involving gel blasters but does not provide any direct connection to water or Walmart's water transforming into a gel.

Walmart Offers Way To Turn Leftover Opioids Into Useless Gel
============================================================
] January 17, 2018 / 5:27 AM CST / CBS Texas
*   
*   
*   
Walmart is helping customers get rid of leftover opioids by giving them packets that turn the addictive painkillers into a useless gel.
The retail giant announced Wednesday that it will provide the packets free with opioid prescriptions filled at its 4,700 U.S. pharmacies.
The small packets, made by DisposeRX, contain a powder that is poured into prescription bottles. When mixed with warm water, the powder turns the pills into a biodegradable gel that can be thrown in the trash.
Research has shown that surgery patients often end up with leftover opioid painkillers and store the drugs improperly at home  
Walmart says the powder also works with other prescription drugs.
The company says its pharmacy customers can request a free packet at any time.
_(© Copyright 2018 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)_

Query2.title: Supercooled Water in the Freezer | Physics Van | Illinois
Query2.snippet: Water normally freezes when it is cooled below 0 degrees Celsius, forming ice crystals. Ice crystals form more easily when they grow on existing ice crystals.

content.content:
_Most recent answer: 10/22/2007_
Q:
I put a bottle of water in the freezer every night before bed. In the morning, I take it out and drink it. Sometimes its frozen solid, sometimes it stays liquid, depending on when I put it in there. But here’s the kicker, sometimes I will pull the bottle out, it will be liquid, but as soon as I open it, it starts to turn into ice, from the top down (it takes a few seconds for the entire bottle to freeze. Is there an explanation for this?  
\- Greg (age 26)  
Army, Iraq
A:
We suspect that what’s happening here is that the water in the bottles which did not freeze overnight was "supercooled." Water normally freezes when it is cooled below 0 degrees Celsius, forming ice crystals. Ice crystals form more easily when they grow on existing ice crystals -- the water molecules like to pack themselves in place on a crystal that’s already gotten started. It doesn’t take much to start the crystallization process going -- a little piece of dust or other impurity in the water, or even a scratch on the bottle are sometimes all it takes to get ice crystals growing. The process of starting off a crystal is called "nucleation."
In the absence of impurities in the water and imperfections in the bottle, the water can get "stuck" in its liquid state as it cools off, even below its freezing point. We say this supercooled state is "metastable." The water will stay liquid until something comes along to nucleate crystal growth. A speck of dust, or a flake of frost from the screw-cap falling into the bottle are enough to get the freezing going, and the crystals will build on each other and spread through the water in the bottle.
Water releases 80 calories per gram when turning from a liquid to a solid. We suspect your freezer is only a few degrees Celsius below zero(perhaps ten or fifteen?), and the specific heat of water is one...[Content truncated]

While it may not specifically address the claim about Walmart-brand water, it can provide scientific explanations pertinent to the freezing and supercooling of water, which can help debunk misinformation.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses the phenomenon of supercooling and how water can remain liquid below freezing until disturbed. It directly addresses the claim of water transforming into a gelatinous substance, explaining that it's a process related to freezing and that the water can solidify suddenly under certain conditions. This helps debunk the claim as it shows there's no harmful transformation into a gelatinous substance.

Query2.title: Why does water freeze instantly when you hit a bottle just out of the ...
Query2.snippet: It is because the liquid in the bottle is supercooled - the temperature of the liquid is below its normal freezing point, but the liquid has still not turned ...

content.content:
Why does water freeze instantly when you hit a bottle just out of the freezer? - BBC Science Focus Magazine
===============
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
(purple://app/menu/open)
!
Why does water freeze instantly when you hit a bottle just out of the freezer? © Getty Images
© Getty Images
Why does water freeze instantly when you hit a bottle just out of the freezer?
==============================================================================
There is a super cool answer to this one...
* * *
**Asked by: Marc McDonald, Omagh**
It is because the liquid in the bottle is supercooled - the temperature of the liquid is below its normal freezing point, but the liquid has still not turned into a solid. That's because it needs something to kick-start the freezing process and encourage a small number of the liquid molecules to get together in a regular arrangement, as they do in a crystal, instead of moving around independently as they do in the liquid.
The process is called nucleation, because it encourages the molecules in the liquid to form a crystal-like nucleus onto which others can then latch. The kick-start can be given by a piece of dust, a rough spot on the surface of a container, or the shock wave generated when you hit a bottle just out of the freezer. Shock waves from an in-built metallic 'clicker' are used in a new 'wine warmer' which contains a supercooled liquid that releases heat as it solidifies.
**Read more:**
*   
*

QA.Question: Does the video demonstrate Walmart-brand water transforming into a dangerous gelatin substance as claimed?
QA.Answer: The claim that a video shows Walmart-brand water turning into a dangerous gelatin substance is not supported by the evidence from the video or from scientific understanding. In the video, the water undergoes a process known as supercooling, where it remains liquid even below its freezing point. When the bottle is jolted or disturbed, the supercooled water rapidly crystallizes into ice, appearing almost like a slushy substance, but it does not turn into a gelatinous material. Supercooling is explained in the scientific context; water, when cooled below 0°C can still remain liquid if there are no impurities or disturbances. The rapid freezing occurs because of a process called nucleation which can be triggered by small disturbances or impurities. This phenomenon is frequently demonstrated in experiments involving water bottles, where a sharp impact can cause the water to freeze almost instantly, creating ice formations but not a gelatin substance. Since the transformation described in the claim does not occur in the video—there is no gelatin substance formed, only slushy ice—this leads to the conclusion that the claim about the video is false.
